Sh1Z6wyI0s6DK0gKJ7E8nA.text: Vietnamese noodle bars have slowly infiltrated all of East London, from Clerkenwell through to Old Street and down to the Kingsland Road a.k.a Little Saigon. As with all cheap eats, some are damn tasty, whilst others leave you passed out with your head in the toilet bowl. Cay Tre definitely falls in to the first category! The food is certainly tasty, portions are decent and the price is reasonable. The one downside (and really, it's a positive) is that there are so many tasty sounding dishes to choose from, that sorting through the menu gives me a headache. On my last visit we plumped for some Vietnamese spring rolls (standard), belly pork (really nice), aubergine and pork (mmmmmmmm....) and clay pot cat fish (really great sauce, slightly 'fishy' tasting fish). When we turned up, there was a 30 minute queue. What I really like (which is something that London restaurants should do more) is that they took my phone number and said they would call when my table was ready, meaning I could wait in a pub across the road, and not in the cold. So if you're after Vietnamese food and you can't afford the airfare to Hanoi, Cay Tre is a great substitute!

b9N-KBgFCeoAXPi_NP1iIg.text: came here for dinner with some friends before going to a gig. i love vietnamese food and had read all the favourable reviews on here, so was excited to try it. i ordered the seafood pho and wasn't blown away...i've had better from various other places, i also felt for dinner it was pretty pricey (but would offer better value at lunchtime and before 6). my boyfriend had the mahi mahi curry however and i tasted a bit - it was really delicious. to be fair to cay tre, there was SO much on the menu that looked really good - i went with pho because i love it, but i would love to come back here and try some of the other fish dishes on their menu, and would hope that they were more of stand out for me.

LgvUpNDBxY0GkDqoB1tZGQ.text: A lovely little restaurant with nice, simple decor. The staff are nice and cheery. I went for lunch and enjoyed a lot of lovely food for just £6. Would certainly recommend a late lunch there. It is quiet enough to enjoy your food and company and the staff give the place a warm, fun loving feel.

KsZVIM_SOwgs5b5a69Hqew.text: Queuing isnot a problem so long as what you are waiting for is worth it. Cay Tre certainly is. I like Vietnam, in fact I'd say it is one of my favourite places I have been on my travels. I love the food. Nothing is as warming and soothing as a nice bowl of Pho of a morning. However Cay Tre's strengths really lie with the starters slash/appetisers. Sharing these with freinds is a joy. The summer rolls, the Viatnamese pizza, the beef in betel leaves and the theatre of grilling your own food at the table made for a great meal.The decor is quirky and even though the service can be a touch slow I find all the waiting staff friendly and eager to please. This is a shoreditch keeper for sure.

q41j8ACucT9Qq6B2yPSvnw.text: Great food.  We had starter of wrapped roll, barbecue pork vermicelli, & Mahi Mahi coconut curry along with coconut ice cream, beer & tea for £45.  Noisy environment downstairs, you need to speak loud & not exactly the best place to carry on an intimate conversation. Service is fast & efficient.

E4rJkgeN6bxY-lOk4EyTYQ.text: Cay Tre and Viet Grill are sister restaurants, with the same menu and aiiiiiiiiiiiiite Vietnamese food.Honestly, what is up with the pho in London?  Do European Vietnamese like using thicker rice noodles?  Or is it that the west-coast American pho chains are getting it wrong and wanting everything and everyone to be thin and healthy....Decent pho, good broth (although slightly oily in my opinion).  The standard deep-fried spring rolls were not as meaty as I would like them to be, nor were there huge green lettuce leaves to wrap them in to cut the grease. All in all, great food for the price, not going to lie.  Have frequented Cay Tre purely for this purpose...and to get my semi-decent pho fix!

MS0xE6B-GLpNXkNaOchkiw.text: I came here with a friend and they seated us almost immediately in the downstairs area.  I had the large Hanoi pho and it was huge!  It's supposedly the more modern pho with garlic and herbs but it tasted just like a traditional pho.  I couldn't finish even half of it!  We also shared the beef cooked in lemon juice which was like a beef carpaccio served in a salad.  This was actually more satisfying than the pho. The food was great but they actually came up to us after we paid and asked us if we would move to a table upstairs because they needed our table.  We had some wine left so we just gulped it down instead of moving.  All in all the experience was good and I would probably come here again and try something other than the pho.

UM9PIvA_nXuSw9uv1IayyQ.text: I went here on a Saturday night because its sibling restaurant - Viet Grill - was full. And Viet Grill is my de facto Shoreditch dining room. I love it. The menu at Cay Tre is very very similar, but they don't have the Feudal Roasted Beef which is a MUST at Viet Grill. A Lotus Stem Salad (on both menus) was fresh and zingy, but a pomelo salad with herbs was way too heavy on the herbs. And an order of shrimp cake was all batter on not enough shrimp. But still, the food was generally very good. And reasonably priced. There was something approaching chaos at the front door, with no record of a booking for a party of four (they were shipped off to Viet Grill with promise of a 10% discount, but given that they'd claimed to be full, I wonder what happened...). The main problem with Cay Tre is to do with the ambience. I ate downstairs in the basement and the noise level is absolutely INTOLERABLE. I've never experienced anything like it. I wished I'd gone somewhere else - I couldn't enjoy the meal for a second. It was like a kind of punishing art noise-oriented art installation. They really need to put some softten some of the surfaces to deaden the sound. I'd absolutely use them for a take away as there are some dead cert wonderful dishes. But I won't be eating-in again... I'll stick to Viet Grill.

gQRA832Wk4vp8MjbCu9oXA.text: Cay Tre is one of my favourite restaurants in London. I go to Song Que for cheap and cheerful, but if I want a nice leisurely dinner.. I go to Cay Tre. There is an excellent spread to choose from, and they do excellent seafood dishes. I've tried the famous La Vong grilled fish, and would highly recommend that when you have a table of 2 and up. The waiter will come to your table to cook this starter for you, and it is all very exciting while you look on in anticipation. Your tastebuds won't be disappointed either. For something different, I'd recommend the cat fish - I was pleasantly surprised by how well it was done.. topped with a sweetish gravy of sorts, the flesh is tender and moist. I've never had anything like that anywhere else.. That said, I'd avoid simple noodle dishes like the pho, as Song Que does it better. The beef pho at Cay Tre is a little bland, and portions aren't as big as Song Que. They do a starter portion, but that is hardly worth ordering. I'd recommend Cay Tre if you want to order dishes (that go with rice). Otherwise, if you're just in for a quick bite.. I'd rather go to Song Que, where noodle dishes are their speciality.

kPU9KtzKH3w01E35zBt0YA.text: I quite liked Cay Tre but don't ask my other half as she hated it. I think she would have given it 1 star. I've given it 4 stars as I really liked the lemongrass pork bun noodles and the crab rolls. They were both superb. The pancakes was slightly disappointing and I feel that Song Que's version is much better. Here's the controversial bit - I thought the beef pho broth was initially quite tasty and I could smell and taste some of the spices. However, after the meal I and my wife were extremly thirsty. My personal view is that it's possibly got too much MSG. Unfortunately my wife didn't feel well after drinking most of the broth but I was ok as I'd only had a few slurps.

kn5vWloFO7VZ_obfnx_9FQ.text: Food and value used to be good.I went back to this restaurant to find a renovated place where all the traditional atmosphere went completely lost. The food is just ok nothing more, the customer service is appalling and the outside lunch billboard misleading. Waiters and waitresses are not able to express themselves in English and the manager has zero cross and intercultural skills. A lot of confusion went on regarding the lunch menu, I felt totally upset and wanted to leave the place straight away. Eventually I had to pay an additional 0.50 because I paid by card below £10. There is no free charge cash point anywhere, I asked the waitress whether I could pay by card when I got in she said yes did not mentioned anything about that. A total disaster I was looking to treat myself for a quick lunch after a marketing workshop and I had the worst restaurant experience ever. I will never go back. Busaba much better service and food.

SE5j596Fu-TXCxbLKKaZxg.text: A little on the sticky side, but the food probably tastes better for it. Make sure to try the indochine beef and the chilli salted and peppered squid. Both of which are absolutely to die for. Plus the techni-coloured sign outside makes everything more fun.

-VDx4Eqk1yXeGjmWv13pRw.text: More expensive than the average Vietnamese place and smaller portions, but the food is really good.  The Pho is great with authentic broth.  The BBQ pork vermicelli is yummy and the shrimp spring rolls rock.  This is the best tasting Vietnamese food we've found so far in London apart from going to Shoreditch.  Service and the atmosphere here are good, but the noise level is a bit on the high side.  The wait can be long sometimes as well.

Ovf97EzmrlUP9LJ65WrPcw.text: Food and value Ok. Service awful.We were seated at the restaurant, and a waitress came over asking if we wanted water, to which we replied yes. She brought over two Acqua Panna bottles. Tap water would've done, cheap trick. My glass of prosseco was warm. I had to ask for it to be replaced only by another glass of warm prosecco. The waiters are aggressive and constantly hover over you, pouring your wine and water, so you'll be out quickly and they can turn the tables over. Wouldn't go back.

2MIrYqCLenIqeQmV1T-Q0w.text: Vietnam is one of the poorest countries in the world; as a result of this, they are a predominantly agrarian society. In addition, the country boasts a very diverse landscape which means different regions utilizing the local fruits and veggies making Vietnam a culinary adventure with tons of fresh, amazing foods no matter what part of the country you may find yourself.Within this context, it's no surprise that a lot of Vietnamese restaurants in this city, (especially the overrated shops on Kingsland Road) don't really measure up . The exception, of course, is Cay Tre. I had seen people queue up to get in this place for a long time, making a mental note to pop in on a less crowded night. This rarely happens. I managed to squeeze in at 11pm on a Friday and 9pm on a Sunday (hardly prime dining time in this city). I fully understand why there is always a queue. This is the best Vietnamese I've tasted outside of Vietnam itself. I particularly like how they point out in their menu various dishes that are local specialties - so you can get an idea of regional favorites throughout the country. I also like that they boast an extensive and detailed wine list - it turns out Vietnamese food pairs well with a variety of wines. And finally, this food is so fresh and delicious, it's a must for anyone who loves this type of cuisine.

bA0zMtw7x6-plVVM50UDnw.text: I love Vietnamese, but I'm really picky. I judge on two things: summer rolls and pho. I have to order these two things no matter what Vietnamese place I go and therefore I have alot of experience, or opinions, built up. Cay Tre does not disappoint on either, but the peanut sauce is just ok. I also want hoisin and/or sriracha available. I told you, I'm a snob. Where Cay Tre actually excelled was in their take away. I ordered my usual and went to get it. I brought it home and it was perfect. Even if I had to assemble a few things, it was still pretty dang perfect. Impessed the heck out of me!

wcwXu5IhfWMKxx_tPhZEEQ.text: I went here for the second time last week for an impromtu dinner with a friend and had a sumptuous meal. It was full when we arrived but we only had to wait 10 minutes for a table. The La Vong grilled fish which is cooked at your table for 2 people was absolutely delicious as was the sizzling seafood and the squid. Service was impeccable and we enjoyed  a fabulous bottle of wine. I can't wait to come back!

Idqvnc-9owvm63xLYgM1Pw.text: Mega popular restaurant, which makes for a hectic, upbeat atmosphere. Even at 7pm on a Wednesday night people were queuing on the pavement. Because of this, service is friendly-rushed with lots of glass filling and asking if you want anything else. But that's ok - they really do have a busy restaurant to run. Food is fresh and enjoyable. It doesn't particularly stand out from all the other places on Kingsland Road, but you won't go far wrong here. Prices are reasonable and they do take bookings.

fdO1ntsdQISdZWmDBVsVdw.text: Had some pho!  Large portions and very friendly service despite being packed with people.  The pho was not the best one I've ever had but did the job!  My friend ordered the mackeral, which she thought didn't taste "Asian" enough - the lemon grass was a bit too subtle.  But will definitely come back to try other dishes (I feel like I ordered the wrong dish)

Q8hrIFmYD-wiisq2CQS28Q.text: Best Vietnamese in London. Price is good too. Highlyrecommended.

Yyiv6gt8t3ZbiNBzzsC54g.text: The two stars we're leaving for this restaurant is for the food. It would've been three stars, however, the service was that bad that we had to only give it a two star. We arrived to the restaurant before noon and there was only one other party there besides ourselves. The staff is not vietnamese and does not understand vietnamese. This is definitely ok, but we received attitude based on our attempt to explain things. Our appetizer took about 15 minutes to get with our drinks and the rest of our food ( two orders of pho and two orders of beef noodle soup) took almost an hour later. This is really unacceptable based on there only being one other party there besides us. My husband went to go check in with them and there insisted it was coming. When it was time to pay the bill, the waitress displayed horrible customer service. Not only was her demeanor not friendly, but there was no thank you or greeting goodbye as we departed. It you want descent Vietnamese food, come here. However, if customer service makes a difference in your meal, we wouldn't recommend this restaurant.

l2jAmUWeOlKeVA38VhGCnw.text: I have been to this place a couple of times, cuz it's right down the street from me, luckily :) Cay Tre is great and always packed for that matter, so prepare to stand in line (they do have take out though)! The Pho is amazing and pretty cheap considering the size (especially for Shoreditch). The only reason why I am giving 4 and not 5 stars is, because i think Cay Tre should offer more vegetarian potions, but despite that it's an amazing restaurant where you get great quality for the price. The restaurant staff is Vietnamese as far as i can tell, so their English is not the best, but it adds to the flair. Additionally, the food doesn't take like a European-version-of-Vietnamese-food, which I love (and i am hoping to find for Thai food some time soon!)

ZYsvJwomq5fgIgq-bGzq1A.text: Vietnamese is in and judging by the queues outside this place this is where it's at. This is really authentic vietnamese cuisine that's packed full of flavour.Service is hit or miss but the food is always excellent. The prices don't quite match the café style interior. It's definitely more restaurant prices.

LbrvYGAfFjQWbKUnPZ_u-g.text: I have been here twice and both times I was really pleased.The service is quick, the prices are low, and the food is FRESH! You can decide if you want to be healthy, and get some Pho with fresh vegetables and clear broth, or you can be naughty and get some delicious fried calamari or duck pancake. Or you can be like me and get all of it, and just hope that the vegetables cancel out the fried.I would highly recommend it to anyone on a budget, looking for healthy food in the Hoxton area.

BkrFHHV1bQXjh7VlmBRMXA.text: I am always skeptical of "in between" Asian places. By in between I mean nice enough so they can command a higher price and attract white people (or more appropriately, not scare off people scared of sketchy-looking Asian places), but not SUPER expensive and high end like, say Nobu. This usually means higher prices for more mediocre food. I usually prefer the dives with great cheap food or the really amazing worth your money type places. While Cay Tre looks like one of those in between places (nice ambiance, white people eating there, long lines, well dressed staff, stylish, etc), the food was surprisingly solid. I had the Hanoi Pho, and the broth was good. Not as good at Pho 14 in Paris, but really solid. The small bowl is REALLY small. Get the large unless you just want a snack. Worth your time and money, especially if you're bringing a friend who is skeptical of Vietnamese food or never had it before. You won't have to worry about odd ingredients common in "authentic" Pho, like tripe. No tripe here. A nice balance of accessible and authentic.  *sluuuuuuurrrrrrrrrrrppppppppp*

FKFT3zCLi_sAZXyMGK0VVw.text: I suppose it isn't fair to judge this place given that I've had the real deal in Ho Chi Minh City and think Viet food is much better in NY and TX.  It isn't bad - def better than places like Pho in Westfield.  Overall, it's okay - the summer roll I felt was alright and would've preferred a peanut sauce as a dip.  The beef & chicken pho... I think my biggest criticism on this was the taste of the broth - only way to describe it as... dull.  Also, I felt the noodles were a little too soggy and thought it was more like a pad thai like noodle than what you would expect in pho.  I'm willing to give this place another shot but would probably try places up Kingsland Rd.  I do really like the ice jasmine tea.

t1mdfw-JRfvYXLVLAzqQGA.text: Good Vietnamese food with nice service. Got the pan fried tofu and shaking beef. Really liked both.

0liTNjrh1TI8Ip78sQrgwA.text: I tried the classic pho. The beef broth tasted really nice and sweet. The beef brisket was also very tender and juicy. My Vietnamese friend recommended this place to me and you know it must be good if a local says so.

4UsI86ETTIR38YD5I_Koag.text: This is one of my top ten favourites in London. I should also disclose that I'm Vietnamese, born in Vietnam and therefore grew up eating lots of Vietnamese. The chef here is good. It's mostly authentic Vietnamese but with modern touches - but the modern touches make sense and makes the food tasty. Dishes have been designed to bring out the flavours in the ingredients, the ingredients are fresh and sensibly combined and the dishes are cooked fresh. Prices are very reasonable. The pho is one of the best in London. Up there with Song Que and Viet Cafe. I know some purist will say this is not 100% authentic Vietnamese due to modern touches. Although I generally love authentic food and usually prefer it, I prefer good tasting modern food over bad tasting authentic food. Authenticity is over-rated in many cases.

eZA9Khrnt2KfizEA-ODnKw.text: Excellent place! I hardly give 5 stars for any place (and I have reviewed quite a few), but this place has the right combination of value and amazing food. Usually places fall into one or the other, but this Vietnamese restaurant falls into both categories. I highly recommend the Indochine beef (although onion haters would do well to stay away). The soft spring rolls are good, not too salty and very fresh. The catfish was nice too, but the sauce is very salty and it is best to order some rice to go with it! We also had a bowl of beef Pho to end our meal (you have to have Pho when eating Vietnamese!) and it was good. It wasn't as flavoursome as the one from Pho in Westfield, but I suspect they use MSG or flavourings in Pho, whereas here it feels more homemade and original. Service was also very prompt even though it was a crowded Saturday evening, and the food came quickly. I will definitely be bringing my friends back here again!!

U_lLkftK7E0aupyffR6rXA.text: Very crowded, very loud.  The starters we had were okay -- they weren't anything spectacular.  The pig on a stick was a little disappointing -- something about the spongy texture of the meat.  The restaurant really won with its main courses.  The braised red sea prawns were sweet and delightful.  The sauce was delicious -- the right combination of spices.  The campfire steak had a real burst of flavor.

r1DdfEV1Is_onHPIdiKVbg.text: This was Pho-Tastic.Actually my first ever time having Pho and will not be my last. I had the "Bun bo hue" meaning the imperial capital's spicier versionof "pho", made with round white noodles, lemongrass and whole chillies and in my case Beef.Soooo delicious. Amazing flavorful broth. I've never had anything like it. The lemongrass and the chillies together gave it quite a unique flavor that I don't think would be too spicy for anybodies taste buds, but was PACKED with flavor. The beef was cut nice and thin and soaked up the broth nicely. My only complain is that the noodles while cooked perfectly seemed immune from soaking up any of the flavor. Pull them out of the tasty broth, they were as white as snow!There might is some crazy Vietnamese technique where they combine spoon and chop stick usage to pack both in one bite, but I could not figure it out.BIG TIP: The small portion of this Pho was 4 pounds(pretty good deal), but the large is only 6 pounds and I'd say it is 3 times big. Splurge and take the extras home for takeaway/.I will back to try more of the menu asap because I am already craving some Pho.Soo close to 5 stars(and could be soon)!

Oem2GhWRUWA-fIF29yR0Sw.text: Food was excellent and tasted fresh. The broth in the Pho was flavoursome. Its a bit on the pricey side for this part of town but the food makes up for it. Jackfruit icecream and the iced drip coffee are a find. Service was fast and efficient and no point was it rushed even though given how busy it was. Would have given it five stars but for the nasty waitress who greeted us at the door, all the other staff were lovely.

IzWHQIeVa4ONPv9esjQPrw.text: This is a funny little restaurant; it serves really good Vietnamese Cuisine at really affordable prices. It is a great prelude to a night out in Shoreditch. If you want to go for dinner  do make sure you reserve in advance as it gets packed. When I was  there the first time, I saw how busy it was and actually thought, my food is going to take forever after we order, to my surprise, they are so organized in the kitchen that in a blink my food was served. If you go you must try the classic Vietnamese noodle soup, it is so scrumptious, and  a perfect  pick me up if you have a bit of a cold or just need to TLC,  it s a healthy soup packed with vitamins. Every time I go there, which is quite often, and mostly with a group of friends, we order lots o food and wine, and never have we paid over  £23 per person. So I highly recommend a visit to this restaurant.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom

m2ndAa5N1iSV8oBjUC8mcQ.text: Great value, quick and friendly. I had a lunch menu - £10 for summer rolls, rice and a pork chop with vegetables. My partner had a very competent take on bun bo nam bo (warm noodle salad with beef) for less. Overall the flavours were excellent with all the lightness you expect from Vietnamese food. That's saying something considering my pork chop was breaded and deep fried...

dsN-7xQZKGeBKdOwxfU0JQ.text: As a massive pho addict I need a fix every couple of weeks and searched for a half decent place nearby. I couldn't wait to taste some traditional broth. Unfortunately,  what I was served by my very efficient waitress was rather pitiful. I ordered the pho classic and asked for it 'tai' which is just the rare sliced beef instead of all the fatty other bits. When the warm ( not hot!) broth arrived i was disappointed to discover it was bland and oily. No amount of basil, fish sauce, lemon or hoisin could make it taste as good as many other pho's i've eaten in the past. Not to mention my noodles were overcooked and the sliced beef looked a lot like minced beef. It's like they reheated a bowl from earlier in the day or something. Granted it was after 9pm and maybe they were running low but the broth should be tastier the longer it's left. As I was starving I just ate the noodles quickly so I could rush home to watch the Usain Bolt race. I check the bill and am suprised to see a 1.19pound charge on top of my 9pound bowl of crappy pho. Ask the waitress what the charge was for but she was unable to explain and asked to speak to another waiter and he said it was for a tip. Since when do Vietnamese restaurants force you to tip??? I let him know the pho was far from good and he said ok don't have to pay for the service charge. I don't know if anything else is any good in the restaurant but I definitely wouldn't go there for their 3/10 bowl of pho.

WjtO5HN81x9QW005YsRt8w.text: Carefully modified to fit the western palate.

yRtSGFN5VKL4BIQ-uN-_pw.text: Cay Tre is like my second home. You might think I am exaggerating. I am not - Cay Tre is literally is on my door step. The good thing is about it, it is in fact on of the best Vietnamese in whole London. The bad news is, that I can not resist going there all the time.Lets describe this place to you. There is always a queue outside of the restaurant willing to wait up to 20 minutes until a table gets available. If you go in a group I recommend making a reservation. Spying on the customers, there are lots of Vietnamese business people choosing that Vietnamese place as their favourite.The decoration is more stylish then the other Vietnamese restaurants at Kingsland Road. They have wallpaper, which looks like a drawing from an artist especially commissioned. Little colourful lights are randomly placed all over it.Now here is a list of recommendations:* Mackarell fish* Vietnamese spring rolls (not the fried ones but with fresh vegetables)* Chilli pork chop with rice and vegetablesCay Tre likes to pride themselves of their numerous won awards, I have to say, this is deserved! As with me, I usually do not eat there, but rather order a take away, which costs me £5.50 for a chilli pork chop, rewarding myself after a hard day of work - what better then having my favourite food is ready in 5-10min!

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Interior with lights and wallpaper
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Night outside Cay Tre

SyWH3WXoBXQqGFOqez-meA.text: I've never had a bad meal at Cay Tre, or a long wait (which for Hoxton is saying something). Be forewarned, they give you a lot of food. I've had the fresh tofu curry which was excellent, as was the saigon xe pancake starter. I know the fusion asian concept is a bit questionable, but I do recommend trying Cay Tre out for yourself.

gMiwwXel_2ilIZ4ckCPVug.text: For some reason there are lots of Vietnamese restaurants in the Shoreditch area but this one is one of the oldest and, in my opinion, one of the best. It's retained it's quaint charm even though it's heaving pretty much every night of the week and the food is very very reasonably priced - and great quality too! The only thing I would complain about is that because it's quite a small restaurant you have to share a four person table with another couple if there are just two of you - which is sometimes a bit annoying if you want to have a private conversation but this is just a tiny thing. Normally there is such a buzzing atmosphere no one is going to be listening any way :)

1srUBDb0AviQx3qzHjzbxQ.text: Perfectly acceptable Vietnamese place, good flavour, portion sizes not massive, prices reasonable. I came here once in 2010 and went again this weekend and both times was overall pleased with the dining experience. There was a long queue outside so booking several days ahead is advised if you want to dine here on the weekend.

BGxErB6sotdni6lLNAxACA.text: Pho was good but service wasn't up to par and it was quite expensive for what it was. One of the waiters had intense b.o. And as much as I tried to sympathise, it was just impossible to enjoy the food when he was walking past every couple of minutes. We asked for water but had to ask a couple of times before we got it. Also when they cleaned the table next to us, they wiped the pieces of food onto my legs. Pricing wise-  I thought 6.50 for 2 tiny chicken wings was crazy expensive. And for 11£ I thought the bowls of pho would be slightly bigger or have some more noodles. Overall I can't help but feel ripped off from my experience. Each incidence on its own wouldn't have made me give such a review but all together I can't say I would visit this location again.

vGb6nYrqLnil-v5ca-HvcQ.text: Its meh, I am a Pho snob and heard that this was the place for Pho in London. The noodles were over cooked and the place was too packed, like get bumped everytime someone passes packed. Also, they used mint instead of basil, lemon instead of lime and maybe scary parts of the cow. With all that said, the broth was wonderful and the waitress was very pleasant. I will continue my search for better (and more affordable) London Pho.

yrWzsVLD8SlxyzNgd5yafA.text: Great restaurant. Beauuuutiful pho and I highly recommend the salt and pepper squid. The atmosphere is bustling and great for a catch up with friends. Highly recommend!

CipVyfIQyQPnzDVKTxXCZQ.text: Cay Tre is my to-go Vietnamese place! After exclusively having their pho for about two years now, I finally decided to switch it up and what a treat it was!We ordered the piggy aubergine (so soft it melts in your mouth & it definitely had that great caramel quality you get with Japanese miso aubergine. Maybe a little too sweet, but still yummy!)The salt and pepper squid was also stunning. Light, crispy skin and cooked to perfection - so tender and not a hint of chewiness. The spring onion, garlic and chili stir fry it comes with, ah that will blow you away! I don't know what makes it taste so good (MSG? Oops) but it is so fragrant!!! I really wanted more :(We also had the mango sea bass and it was almost like a mix of both. Fish cooked really well, crispy on the outside but firm and juicy on the inside. With sliced mangoes and a similarly sweet sauce (again, really very very sweet).The two of us shared all that and a bowl of egg fried rice (definitely a sharing portion), and we left having spent about £15 each, feeling pretty darn satisfied. A+ as always!

k4koZ7QC-DVpYamc_YIBTw.text: Authentic, delicious and worth the wait if you have to, it's a busy place and well deserved of it, if you love Vietnamese food this is the place

PR6LgomA2gzXrbZCenQvRw.text: Have been to Cay Tre on several occasions and have been very pleased. Last time I did however feel that something had changed. The place was not as full as usual and the menu had changed slightly and felt less authentic. The food is however still very good but the prices seem to have gone up and the service is not as good as it used to be.Can however still recommend the Ph, spring rolls and Bánh xèo and it is one of the better options for dinner in the area.

w-69AKB88zJ-NLpX6Nkd_g.text: Being from San Francisco I can only base my review on what I know: Bay Area Vietnamese food and service.Both were not very good.  When your £6 spring rolls crumble when you pick them off the plate from the rice noodle paper being too sticky, it's a rough start to your dinner.  My pho ga was too bland with very little chicken, heavy noodle and onion.  Service was poor, although the staff were nice.  Seemed overrated and trendy.

XugbljfNz8XFi8RI1dXGJw.text: Decent enough place for lunch. Haven't been there in a while, but they did a special lunch menu where you could pick many of the popular items for around £6.The food however is a bit of a mixed bag. The seafood pho is great, lots of seafood, large portions. However getting anything with chicken is a world of pain. Somehow the chicken they used are the scrawniest of the bunch, thus lots of bone. Plus seem like the discarded bits of meat. It's still tasty, but as much as eating plain rice with sweet and sour sauce. Not impossible, but unsubstantial. Leaving you hungry when leaving.The place is quite small and cosy, making a winter lunch visit very pleasant. The aroma of the food drifts through the restaurant. Just make sure you order a pho dish, preferably seafood and have a little more than an hour to have your meal (service is slow as a result of the busy lunch rush).

1LUN-jwSdIDOdOjkG0duOg.text: I have officially found the best pho place in Europe. I got the Saigon Pho and it has exceeded my expectations. Coming from Seattle where there is a huge Viet population, I was really disappointed with in Europe. I have gone everywhere from Amsterdam to Prague to Dublin and nothing compares. The broth is so flavorful, marinating for 48 hours. And the noodles are so fresh and soft. And the beef is perfectly sliced with the right amount of fat. My friend got the campfire steak and it is delicious. The right amount of sauce where it's not overly salty and the beef is very tender. It also comes on a firing plate which is a great presentation. My only critique is it does not come with rice so you have to order it on the side but overall it was a wonderful experience, great atmosphere and over the top food!

9a4UHLx4QaQkdO30yzY9DQ.text: I am a massive fan of Vietnamese cuisine, for me it is almost a cross between Thai and Chinese with a French influence in the mix, and Cay Tre is one of the few places in London that managed to pull it off without engineering it to suit the western palate. This time around we went as a large group and went for the less known dishes.  The new dish Bo Ne Saigon steak was a take on a classic Vietnamese street cafe dish, sizzling steak with pork pate, egg and onions. The rib eye steak was super tender with a great depth of robust flavours, pork pate was well seasoned and overall a very well executed dish....

GyK0vGQcZBryt6HDLgaKAQ.text: The food was okay. The service was bad. Don't come here alone.... They will make you wait for soooooooo long. I've been waiting  here for 30 minutes to get the pho ... The pho was okay to eat, the spring roll was amazing ;(((( even though the service wasn't that pleasant ；（ I might come back next time, maybe next time won't wait that long. Good luck folks! Forgot to say the dessert fried banana with coconut ice cream was amazing too:))))

u7XNg_Pc3MAeaLEheeVjMA.text: + consistent quality across Cay Tre franchise+ seating area downstairs+ waiting staff do not rush at non-rush hour- priceyCay Tre seems to be everywhere these days! It's good to know that there is consistency across all its outlets in terms of quality and taste. This particular Cay Tre has a downstairs area that accommodate larger groups should you get there early enough. Five of us came for early dinner on Sunday evening and were seated very quickly, and as it wasn't very busy that night we weren't rushed out of the restaurant immediately after we had finished our meal, which was a nice touch. Maybe it's the location, Cay Tre's reputation, or maybe my wages not keeping up with inflation, but dishes are getting a bit pricey (almost £10 for a bowl of vermicelli noodles with grilled pork).

RrowdPgzU6YKLzIsUM2LbQ.text: What Vietnamese place runs out of every type of Pho 2 hours before closing time...??? This plus the leaking roof above our heads made this the worst Vietnamese food experience I've ever had.

I6pZgcde0sGgL_5Ej3ggGw.text: I don't go here often. strange especially given that i lived up the street for a year.The ambiance (or lack thereof?) just doesn't do it for me. i know that you don't go to a place for the decor, but it helps.the food is damned tasty though. and not too hard on the wallet as well.I generally get one of the massive (like 2 meals worth at least) bowls of pho/noodles/soup/etc. its good, but i wouldn't go out of my way for it.

sC8mZUqi_ZNnhcIqtj-npA.text: BYOB and an extensive menu. Everything I have tried there was great! But I did drink a whole bottle of wine to myself so make of that what you will (the danger of BYOB). Great for big parties and service is usually speedy.

HhjWYRIkI5uNtEf4ZWmS4A.text: Because of the great reviews on yelp I decided to try Cay Tre during my layover in Shoreditch. I'm so lucky that the host got me in!  I was by myself and he was kind enough to find me a table even though the place was packed. That was the best pho I've ever had. I had the house pho or traditional (I forget what it's called but it had 2 kinds of beef). It was absolutely delicious. The broth!!! Wow.  I'm from the states and I've had pho before but it always seemed so bland to me. Not this bowl. I go to London 1-2 times a year and now Cay Tre will be on my MUST list. Thank you to the host and to my kind server. You made me a big fan.

vFwYzpj7L67MkbwDKfQKzQ.text: Great Viet for fresh, tasty & inexpensive food. Great Pho! BYO too! What more could you want!!

XTYJnkr8tbB9GQJpVgl-kw.text: Food is not bad but the service was terrible when we went.  Granted it was a busy evening but our dishes came out without rice.  We had to remind them 3 times to bring out the rice and by the time it did come out, the rest of the food was already cold.  We were so annoyed we asked for the service charge to be removed.The food wasn't good enough for us to put up with this level of poor service.  Their Soho cousins are much better in this regard.

U9wcmsBeMIqaFTFbjB1OBA.text: Amazing food!My party was seated in the lower level, which had a nice atmosphere. The seating is very tight, but that seems typical of most Vietnamese places in Hoxton.We tried a selection of starters and a few rolls and wraps. I highly recommend the Piggy Grilled Aubergine and Vietnamese Beef Carpaccio.We were so pleased that we stuck around for dessert and a few more drinks. The wait staff were all friendly and helpful, and anything extra that we ordered was always delivered to our table in short order.If the prices were just a bit more reasonable, it would be a 5 star in my book.

SXvK2JShSUMuuyB_weaBuA.text: If you like Vietnamese and you haven't heard of Cay Tre, let me have the pleasure of  introducing you . I have taken so many friends here - during the day, at night and recently I ventured to their new branch in Soho - owned by Vietnamese Kitchen they also have couple of other spots around Shoreditch.On this occasion it was going to be the original venue. Naturally with these places with so much good food you have to order to share, but the portions are so generous it's a good effort to get through one main, nevermind sharing two!We went for the Butter Fish Curry with jasmine rice and the Bun Sa noodle bowl.The Butter Fish Curry is made with dried tamarind, coconut milk & red curry and is so intensely comforting and the spices are so harmonious you just feel like a better, happier person for eating it - dramatic but true.In contrast, the Bun Sa is a refreshing zingy and clean, noodly mouthful! A huge bowl of vermicelli  rice noodles, cucumber, bean sprouts, mixed Vietnamese herbs, crispy shallots, peanuts, nuoc cham with sautéed lemongrass and rather meaty red sea prawns.A seriously authentic place for some fresh and mouthwatering Vietnamese that's well within budget. C.x

whD-qrDOdytotIhazVOPqg.text: I think I used to like Cay Tre more. Well, I've always liked it less than Qui Viet, but it was OK...  Then I discovered Coba. So, I got really drunk on their awesome party punch, but didn't think very much of their food.There is nothing wrong with the food at Cay Tre per say, and as others say, it is the perfect place to fill a hole when out around old street.  However, with so many around this area, Cay Tre was never my first port of call (see Qui Viet point). It's fine. It's kinda tasty but very rough around the edges, and the menu never really appealed- it sits in this weird area between really cheapass vietnamese food and slightly more "refined" vietnamese food...We shared a wrap & roll platter, some soft shell crab and the piggie aubergine.  It was all fine, but nothing to write home about.  Basically if I never came back, I would never miss it.  It's not so bad I have an opinion about it, but it's not so good I would choose to come back either.Service was quite dicey but expected the week before christmas and also we were a party of 16.P.S. I know a lot of people hated House of Ho, but I also prefer it to this.

np8YyUW_G3C5ECUqIQzKhQ.text: In my quest for the perfect pho, I've found myself in cay tre... Not for the first time. I'm looking for my perfect bowl and I'll be fair, cay tre does come pretty close. In my pho reviewing career, probably the closest.The pho is always perfectly cooked, it is smooth, but not overcooked. The toppings - whichever one you go for are also on point. My litmus test is usually the beef balls - I like it with some tendon and elasticity, the beef balls are great here!! The soup is flavourful and abundant, I just have to drink all the soup after a satisfying meal. So far so good.So why four stars? Firstly, my generic frustration with London is why we charge extortionate fees for bowls of soup noodles. I'm sure this resonates with most. I understand the margins and so forth, but let's admit it, the bull of your pm should come from drinks. Leave the food alone. Anyway, secondly, pho would probably tip the 5 star mark alone, a bit more herbs and bean sprouts on my herb plate is really all I ask. Lastly, the sides that I've had are a bit hit and miss. I personally prefer the summer rolls in city caphe over the summer rolls at cay tre. They skimped on the vermicelli and meat and overdid the herbs. I ain't no herbivore. Having said that, I've had this wonderful 'piggy aubergine' in old st cay tre which was deliciously meaty and vinegary. Yum.I do like cay tre and in a world of expensive pho and overcompensating (to the point of rude, you know who I'm talking about, Song Que) Vietnamese restaurants. For now, find me in Cay Tre.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Piggy aubergine @old st branch
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Skinny summer rolls
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Beef ball Pho!!! Woot woot

2Ck7-c4GB2JDGMJBqmZTnA.text: To me I have always heard about the place through the buzz on blogs online and through word of mouth. A Vietnamese place that does it properly. A Vietnamese place that is authentic. A Vietnamese place that is unique it doesn't need to be on Kingsland Road amongst all the others fighting for your attention.When you enter you realise it's much smaller than you anticipate. The outer signage seems very, well, tacky in truth. But no matter we're here for more than just that.In terms of space inside it's quite crowded and close knit. You'd often find yourself squeezing in next to other diners. Food was good. Very good if washed down with some proper Saigon beer. I think the quality may have dropped a tad from when I first ever went as well as rising prices due to popularity. However the food was indeed good.Spring rolls, mango salad, chilli salt pepper squid, even had a table griddle beef (tho this was very tricky as table we had was tiny! - prob wouldn't try that again), as well as a Vietnamese red duck curry. All personal favs.All in all. Very good. I'm always a bit disappointed with the pho in London so haven't ventured back to any restaurant to try again, including here but maybe next time I will be adventurous.

k1NC-DNwEv7Mg8LFv1LBAQ.text: Who'd think I'd come to London after living in Asia and the US all my life and discovered the best Saigon Pho I've ever had? A total gem.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Saigon Pho, Cay Tre

ZwR-JP4HlH21FNlW5XLRhw.text: This place serves really good vietnamese food. I must admit I was not expecting those flavours. I thought only Indian food had flavours. But this one was a sure surprise. I've gone here twice with my colleagues and you get really large tables to dine with a big team if you want. The staff is friendly too and items on the menu are pretty decently priced. Some funky cocktails too. I remember having the wok roasted beef with rice and vegetables. I also had some spring rolls and a cocktail that I don't remember the name of, which contained a mix of some champagne, aloe, mint, lime etc. But I did have an unforgettable experience here as I almost passed out after my lunch. It certainly wasn't the food. And it was probably an allergic reaction to one of the ingredients that I had which I'm still not aware of. But this was the day I got into an ambulance. Thanks to my colleagues for quickly getting me an ambulance. I could barely breathe and I struggled to stay awake. But I was back to normal in about 20 minutes. Thanks to the medics and my friends. I think I caused the restaurant some bad business that day, as this happened soon after I had my lunch and bill was cleared. So they helped with dealing with the emergency and despite this incident I did drop by to apologize for the loss of any customers. They were very kind and asked me to take care and consult a doctor when I can. But you know London, it is hard to get a GP appointment. But I can say for sure, literally, that was a lunch to DIE for. At least that's how my colleagues describe it now.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Collage of everything I had from there. The lunch to die for
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Spring rolls with a lovely dip
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Ride noodles with I don't remember what. Vietnamese names aren't easy to remember

LRhAXbGLoFLrqDWiUkRxXA.text: Ordered the Garlic Hanoi pho which was sublime, great flavor and it even had whole cloves of garlic nicely seared and added in the broth! Would definitely recommend overall, if it weren't for the absolutely atrocious service here. Waiters are rude, pushy and inattentive. Much of the flatware and glasses were not even close to clean (I had a hair on my plate to greet me as I sat down), and if they happened to be clean they were still severely chipped or scratched. Interesting... considering this restaurant is constantly packed, completely overpriced, and must be doing well! You actually cannot move or walk because it is so cramped, you may as well be sitting on your neighbor's lap. If you live close by, get pho to go and do not bother with the total inconvenience of the restaurant and staff.

8VQOxF9ZKv9V210KopXrmA.text: Last month Cay Tre Old St had a set lunch menu for just under £11 - I ordered the traditional summer rolls (goi cuon) and the very traditional pho bo (beef noodle soup). Both were delicious! A true testament of a good Vietnamese restaurant is it's pho - without a doubt it's one of the best in London. The pho bo was served with several different cuts of beef in deliciously fragrant broth. The summer rolls were expertly rolled - hardly anything dropped out of rolls when I doubled dipped them in hoi sin sauce. Although the hoi dip was tasty it traditional to serve summer rolls with fish sauce dip.Cay Tre's sister restaurant in Soho served one of the best pho chicken (pho ga) I've had - trust me, both my parents are Vietnamese. So far, these are only 2 Vietnamese restaurants I've enjoyed eating at. The portions are smaller than one would expect but nonetheless yummy!My recommendations:StarterPrawn summer rolls MainPho bo (beef noodle soup)

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Goi cuon - prawn summer rolls
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Pho bo - Beef noodle soup

4qiRmkl1pcsLW4O8iTYa9g.text: We had pre booked as it was early evening. We were escorted downstairs and were the first to be seated down there. It soon filled up, but the tables are insanely close to one and you can't move anywhere. When you go to the toilet or leave one whole table had to get up to move out of the way.We ordered several dishes to share and they came back saying it had sold out, strange as it was the beginning of the night. We then ordered some replacements and the same thing happened with that. I then asked them what they had on the menu so it didn't happen again and the waitress was slightly rude back, walked off then came back and we finally finished our order.Food came, it was good but not the best I've had. They threw the dishes down in front of you and ran off.Overall service needs improvement and the general layout needs updating so you don't feel like sardines. Food is good, but maybe avoid peak times when it is less busy. (Visit - 17/08/2015 Dinner)

fDY340ALBlyw8Uv6NFDyEA.text: Our group left here with mix feeling but full stomachs. We enjoyed some of the dishes, including the vermecilli and beef, and the prawn and chicken pancake. However the friend prawn thing (it was just globs of fried was with shell on shrimp inside) wasn't very good at all- biting through shell is not fun. The chicken was standard- juicy but small. Nothing go back for. We sat in the basement which was loud at times and service was a little slow. However the wine and beers were nice and complimented the food well. This place has potential but the food wasn't good enough to make a lasting impression or entice me to ever come back. Portions were larger than expected. While I did not find this, the wide thought the noodles tasted like cleaning detergent. Maybe three stars is too generous? But it's certainty not two so I will round up.

-rlYqlz-NUHTJuc2F2Ws2A.text: You're spoilt for choice on this stretch of Old Street and Cay Tre is definitely a winner.  While Keu! across the road looked quite empty by 9.30 (perhaps I wasn't the only one put off by  the rather pungent cabbage smell wafting down the street ...) we had to join the queue at Cay Tre of the same group of restaurants.  Embarrassing to admit but I forgot to bring my reading glasses and ended up relying on the waiter's recommendation.  The sauteed chicken with lemongrass and chilli won over the pho on this occasion - delicious!!  The dishes served to the tables to both sides looked just as delicious, though, and I will keep coming back until I have eaten my way down the entire menu.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. before
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. after

UQJBBlHhfTJr8SOkaki3FQ.text: Lovely Pho! Been here a number of times and it's definitely one of the best Vietnamese restaurants in Shoreditch, in my opinion. Tends to get really busy so booking a table might be a good idea. Slightly noisy as well but okay for a quick dinner.

8_rfK_v3w0VCGogxY47QlA.text: Yes, my lamb shoulder curry was super tasty, but oh my did we have to wait to get to that point. I did book a table for 8 people at 8.30pm, but wasn't sitting before 9.15pm and we had to be gone for 10pm, so yes, tasty, but I felt like a lack of organisation made us eat in a rush...and you don't really want that on a Friday do you? Yaa, definitely potential here, but disappointed with the way they treated us.

Io5ScoO1R66URMrny-wSVA.text: Delicious BBQ bowl for lunch -- good amount of meat and good amount of vermicelli noodles. Would definitely recommend for a fast and tasty lunch. Would love to try the rest of their menu, stuff on neighbouring tables looked delicious!

wJsnts3-tKV82iDQaC9AQQ.text: Had the Saigon pancake, stuffed crab, and lettuce dumplings and everything tasted good.  The stuffed crab wasn't spicy so a little bland for my taste. We also had the summer rolls and a noodle dish for 45.34 GBP or $74.This was one of the best meals that we had while in London which seems to be full of many overpriced mediocre restaurants.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Leafy dumplings
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Stuffed crab
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Saigon pancake

3jZjCWi6vFD4jXqvHq1blA.text: Whenever you want to grab some fast good vietnamese food, this is always a solid option.Nothing fancy about this place: tables are small and packed, a little bit of dirt in the angles of the room, you don't really want to see the kitchen where your food is coming from. But it's very good food! It's like getting on a flight to Hanoi, everything is real! And more over, it's damn fast, you receive the menu, 5 minutes you order it, 10 minutes max you get your food, out in half hour. That's great on a lunch break.In the end, whenever I want to get back to Vietnam with my mind, its flavors and tastes, I now Cay Tre and her shy waitress, his sweaty cook and his delicious and genuine food are there!Yai!

GFM-OrlsJRRoVXx4L0KbPA.text: Cay Tre is bright, and really friendly looking during the lunch rush. The waitress, although very nice, asked me what I wanted about three minutes after I got the menu. I was pretty set on the Classic Pho, so that was fine, if not preferred. I'm not a huge fan of chatty waitresses. The girl that waited on my table was very nice, and very efficient. The pho was phenomenal. First off, it got to my table incredibly quickly, before my drink had. I'm not going to try to make out like a pho expert, but I've had good pho and I've had bad pho and this was excellent pho. The beef was thinly sliced and delicious, the broth was just the right amount of salty, and the portion  was huge. Absolutely worth £9.50

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Decor
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Classic Pho

rxHNv9JHsvK51lFldb9DLQ.text: This is our go to spot for a quick bite. It hits the spot and they have fast and friendly service. Reasonable pricing as well. It gets pretty busy but we seem to always luck out and get one of the last tables before the rush comes.Cozy atmosphere and pretty typical fare for this area. We will have to try their regular main entree items sometime soon!Chaû gio Crispy Pork Spring Rolls Somerset pork, shiitake mushrooms, glass noodle, nuoc chamBuùn thit nôùng BBQ Pork Loin with Rice Vermicelli lemongrass marinated pork loin, crispy pork spring rolls, daikon and herbsBun Bo Hue 9 The spicy version of Pho from Hue, the old imperial city. Flavored with lemongrass, whole chilies, served with either beef, chicken, Red Sea prawns & crab cake (with prawns or crab cake)Pho classic Vietnamese noodle soup, served with Vietnamese basil, saw-leaf & beansprouts

3KWRI_5DYsrNFlTgnq7TRA.text: For some reason I thought there would be a takeaway counter here so was taken by surprise and then mortified when I was sat on one half of somebody's else's table, with another 2 people inches to my right. The stress continued as I frantically searched on my phone for how to pronounce "pho" (no connection between this and me dining alone, obviously). Is it fuh? Is it foe? I tried fuh and then the server repeated it back to me as "foe". WHAT?So yes, this was my first pho experience. The beef was well cooked and tasty and although I wasn't sure exactly how to add the herbs, lemon etc that came with it, whatever I managed to do with them had a delicious result! Little bit on the expensive side for lunch, really, and I don't find broth particularly filling but I left feeling more or less full and I'm sure I'll be back to try the other options. Service was attentive and friendly. Unlike other reviewers, I thought the decor was quite nice - maybe it's been updated? Maybe I just have boring taste?

aYkNG34c2w4NG2RpkaAQ-Q.text: One of my favourite vietnamese restaurants in east London, big menu to choose from, and always good quality food, service a bit slow sometimes

oI3o8usZiyeTuNTPvJjk0Q.text: 7pm on a saturday night gets you a table quickly ahead of a heavier dinner crowd. We had the seafood and rolls sampler, and the stir fried water spinach. The portions were perfect for our pre-drinks date but the price tag was slightly steeper than expected for the portions. Nonetheless service was friendly and prompt and the dishes came quickly. We loved the seafood sampler of prawns, crab and squid - fried but not greasy and tones of chilli. The roll sample comprised of dumplings, glass noodles and egg rolls. The spinach was again a v modest portion but perfectly seasoned and full of garlic. Can't wait to come back and try the pho!

QfqRYDszotdBODld_rJ9mA.text: by far the best vietnamese restaurant in London.  Pho was quite good, can be compare to those in California (but can never be as good as those Pho restaurant in California)

J6Qy-ghJUYyR8T5UOv8jGg.text: Why did I come to this restaurant? One of the worst bowls of pho I've ever had. No offense, considering I'd had so much authentic pho in my life. Broth didn't have much flavor. The spring rolls were also pretty bad. They were super tiny and three fourths of the roll was just lettuce. On top of that, it was not cheap.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom

qgp2CyCL9kTpZ3Pv3YUQyA.text: My friend and I were looking for a Vietnamese local restaurant close to our hotel in Old Street, with only a 15 minutes short walk we thought we would give this place a shot.I ordered a cha gio chat (Vietnamese egg roll vegetarian) and a pho seafood, the broth was made from chicken broth with fresh seafood. I took a bite of the noodles and was impressed of the taste because it tasted very homemade and fresh (we didn't ask if it was). Their Vietnamese coffee was also sweet wish it was a little stronger. All in all, I enjoyed my experience -- the staff were really nice and kept us in the loop with the wait time of our food. If I'm in London again I would come and support them again. The only downside is the pricing - I think I spent $16 total which is a lot for a Vietnamese restaurant... but again, we ARE in London!

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Seafood pho with some greens in chicken broth
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Vegetable egg roll yum
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Menu

R6dnav_LIXa1sP8IudzC_w.text: Horrible. Worst food poisoning of my life and everyone in my party got sick. would NOT recommend, very sick. and service was poor.

VUtwoqYNkAXsrr4XjdMUPg.text: Decent food, mildly aggressive serviceI ordered a pho dish, it was decent enough and light in flavour however the eating conditions were cramped bordering on communal. The squid starter was very very salty so would recommend going for that unless you have a jug of water at the ready!Good value in terms of price, portion size and flavour however I don't think I will be returning as this place has some great competition in the area.

_nnVr3Hc_Y0t855ZQWK7yQ.text: Delicious food: Pho Lunch Sea Food. Although it is a small place, you feel like home.

KShm1Yh7ThQxBb04H6kOKw.text: Alllll hype no substance. A 30 minute queue in an overbooked noisy restaurant for average Vietnamese/Chinese food? NaaaaaahI don't understand why people go here especially when there are plenty of crazy delicious Vietnamese options near by. I guess the options are huge so you are getting your money's worth but I'd say most of the food options are actually more like Chinese takeout dishes rather than healthy simple Vietnamese dishes. The matcha milkshake I had was on point though but again not very Vietnamese.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Crab vermicelli
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Prawn fritters

aRal6nx7-BEe2NcICwbfDw.text: The worst Pho every in UK i have eaten yet! The broth, the noodle, .... speechless. If you know pho, please dont go here. They do not take like pho they taste like some chicken broth lightly cooked soup

ZViDKF-HG5I2AEAKnQTP8Q.text: Quite decent no frills kinda restaurant close to Old Street. It was pouring with rain so it wasn't hard to get a table but it was still busy inside. I've heard you have to wait a while for a table on non rainy days!I order the chow pho noodles. It's a rice noodle/pho dish with beef. Sooo flavoursome and beefy. Not too much broth either and a good helping of vegetables. Also quite big portion for about £9.The Vijito cocktail was particularly passion-fruity and refreshing - although a bit light on the rum I felt.Service was attentive and quick. Also, I tried Flying Goose Hoisin sauce for the first time. Where can I buy that?? Yum!

CEzE54IXDEZDFvW7kQco-Q.text: Vietnamese classics plus all sorts more.They do pho and they do it pretty well. All they need is some extra flavourings on the table as they can be a touch bland. There is no lack of additional chilli options. There are the standard pho like beef and chicken (including the ultra safe pulled chicken breast) and then all sorts of variations. The beef in the traditional pho is fall apart and really perfectly cooked. But they all need a touch more soy/oyster/vinegar ? fir some extra flavour. The menu is huge and there is lots of well gentrified Vietnamese items to share and snack on. I love love love the crab rolls and the tofu aubergine is delicious. There is a single scallop which is unsharable (it's big but I don't believe in sharing scallops) as one bite wouldn't be enough. There is definitely a 'proximity to old street' tax on the food so if you want something a bit cheaper go around the corner.But it's pretty alright with a good vibe! Do the big menu sharing! It's probably the best way

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Beef pho: beautiful meat, needs a touch more flavour

m1dIXAwYpAYxD_Rc_oncug.text: This is our local "go-to" for Vietnamese "to go" near Old Street. It certainly isn't the greatest in the area (obviously Vietnamese delicacies abound down Kingsland Road), but it is fine. We've eaten in a few times and don't really like the atmosphere (a bit cramped, pretty loud, usually a que) but we've hit the sweet spot with a pick-up routine. The service is always good, either way though! *call 10-15 minutes before you'll be hungry. Order. *Pick up 10-15 minutes later. *Voila! I've had lots of things here, the pho is AOK but I typically do not get that dish as takeaway for the obvious reason that it rarely stands up to being transported. But we often get spring rolls, summer rolls, hot dishes like chicken skewers, fried rice, etc. It's all tasty and I've never had a complaint. Our order is always ready when they say it will be and we are in and out in a flash with our food! *They don't deliver, but they do accommodate takeaway orders swiftly and accurately, which is more than I can say for many area restaurants! They have the correct containers as well, so your food won't be a literal "hot mess" when you get it home. Bonus: the Vietnamese coffee is always a treat!

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom

t9Y_L1K0T9HRr3v5PpOorw.text: We loved this place! 1. Because we got a spot straight away on a busy Friday night. 2. Because they sold wine by the carafe. 3. Excellent service. 4. Amazing vermicelli noodles (like the best!) 5. We were even drooling over everyone else's dishes...! Definitely one to come back to.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Don sa (?) with prawns! Yum!!

LLL8sbi92JD2fwzfx86yEQ.text: In future, just walk that extra 5 minutes to Kingsland road..... summer rolls were flimsy and everything fell out! And they don't have chilli oil.... mains were big but underwhelming- avoid the prawns at all costs. All the prawns are not de-veined - unless you enjoy the taste of the digestive tract of prawns.....:(

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. A poor attempt at summer rolls
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Chicken lemongrass bun sa

9T2Vl_oRJ7O9za62v5D_GA.text: Best go to spot in hoxton!! The food is always quality and at a great standard..staff always accommodates and there are the beers!

es33FlRjVX3GsWvX08-kDQ.text: To be more accurate, I would give Cay Tre 3.5 stars.Food: shrimp spring rolls were mediocre, Saigon pho (aka pho tai) was surprisingly good... Especially for pho in England, and the Bun Thit Nuong was also pretty tasty. The BBQ pork in the bun was perfectly cooked and seasoned but I didn't like the nuoc cham (fish sauce) because it wasn't strong enough, and they don't serve it on the side! Ambiance: it's extremely loud. The music was uncomfortably loud for a Vietnamese restaurant. Because the music is so loud, you pretty much have to yell to be heard.Service: horrible. We were asked to move to a table upstairs midway through our meal. Thanks, but no thanks.In short, come here for the food. Don't expect good service or a quiet meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Pho Tai and Bun Thit Nuong

s-1_PpycePOwU07eG84AGg.text: Excellent Vietnamese on Old Street.The decor is pretty drab and it's always a bit bustly and cramped with people BUT that's because it's so GOOD!!!The Pho's are great - I can recommend the chicken thigh & drum pho with no noodles if you're an aspiring paleo like minded person. They do great summer rolls and lamb neck curry too..All round to nosh!

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Salt and pepper squid - not the healthiest starter on the menu but great garlic and chilli hit to cure any cold :)
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Spicy chicken pho with noodles

yXeROdo8EF6kT2LPECytfA.text: My review is only of the pho, since this is the only dish that we tried on the menu. The service was very quick and the pho was delicious (especially on a cold evening). If you like spicy pho, I definitely recommend adding the peppers at the table into the pho. They are very good and very spicy! As for the seating, they have a few tables upstairs and downstairs (basement). We were seated much sooner, because we were okay with sitting downstairs. The ambiance is much better upstairs, because it is brighter and much more lively. Nonetheless, there is nothing wrong with sitting downstairs, if you are just looking for good pho.

YcbRrwFvPrnGw854vWba8w.text: Best pho I have ever had (I went for the garlicky beef). The broth was very tasty and the beef was tender and juicy. The place is a little small and we had to share table with another couple but the quality of the food made up for that.

4Y1eZcWnk7WrmSKqbF45uA.text: A group of us popped into here for a quick bite after checking out a few bars nearby! There are a few Vietnamese restaurants on the same road but this one attracted us as there was no queue to get in, there was extra seating areas downstairs, and the food look great through the window!  So we walked in and was greeted by a member of staff who asked if we were eating in or takeaway and as we had se time on our hands we ate inside. Probably not the best place to go after having a heavy drinking session as all we could drink was water, but I gotta admit the little jug of water with ice and a slice of lemon looked pretty!So to start off with we shared a Crispy Vietnamese vegetable Spring Rolls which came with some sauces, which was yummy and we could have ordered another but then came our second part of the meal which was a a plate of Wok-fried Ramen Noodle, which had oyster mushrooms, beansprouts, green onions, followed with Campfire Hanger Steak which is  cooked with oyster sauce, onions and the steak was very soft. Once we finished eating it did take the waitress a long time to realise we had finished and wanted to pay our bill as she had disappear for some time but we have been here again since the service was a lot better! Also loved the menu choices as there wasn't too many items to over complicate what to select!

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom

XzRon3rV7T0w-Tu9Ag5bdA.text: I had the bun-bo-hue and it was slightly more than decent (for London); mainly rating by broth. it was GREAT that the noodles were not soggy (vs. every other place I've been to). Unauthentic in that they asked me to choose a meat. And sucked the basil was half dead/black. otherwise, slightly more than decent!

z5CrgzvnzkNZwYTB-scSKQ.text: Cay Tre has changed quite a bit in the past few years, it's a lot more upmarket than it used to be and is way more swanky than many of the vietnamese on Kingsland Road. The prices reflect thi, it's a bit more than you'd pay elsewhere close by and it's not BYO (which many of the others are). BUT, and the important bit, the food is nearly always AWESOME. If you go here, you have to have La Vong grilled fish! It's exquisite. The dish is finished off at your table, where they pan fry it in front of you. The combination of monk fish (which is marinated in herbs and spices), dill, chillis, peanuts and the yummy pink fish sauce is excellent. Another great dish is the Campfire beef, and it is incredibly flavoursome. Both these dishes don't seem to be on many menus along the Kingsland Road establishments and often make it worthwhile to come here just for them. Only downside is the last time we were there we saw a teeny tiny cockroach which the staff didn't seem bothered about..other than that, it's always been great.

CCExmLTiADq11c2nuPdvew.text: I organised a Saturday birthday dinner for my friend there, and it seems that picking this day at the time of 7pm is facing the craziest and busiest time of the restaurants week. It is worth for the experience of the atmosphere-smashing plates, loud volumes so you can only here the person sitting next to you, athletic performance of the staff... in spite of all that, the food and drinks came out within 10 minutes. The food was ok, but to be honest I don't see a great difference with the Vietnamese restaurants on Kingsland road. Next time I'll be going around the corner.

AHGE8dPmQbU2my5_m_7ukw.text: One of my favorite Vietnamese restaurants in London is Cay Tre. I have come with friends and the food is always a hit. Everything is fresh, flavorful, and comes in big portions. My favorite is the cat fish dish in a stone pot, but I've also had the pho, the Vietnamese pizza, the calamari, and their noodle dishes, and the flavors are all spot on. The place is always crowded with all types of people everytime I've gone. The only down side is the service. It's a hit or a miss, but come anyways to check out the food.

n2BHxgLaQiQ_PpNvCMnw-Q.text: Sister restaurant to the legendary Viet Grill Cay Tre is the slightly brasher and buzzier of the two. You can eat like a king here on excellent Vietnamese food for a bargain price. A little more upmarket than your standard Vietnamese place there is no lino, lovely wallpaper and even a decent winelist (although no byo). Go for the soft shell crab or pho.

1YYm5tdRjmQhZmp9YepwDA.text: This review is mainly about the Pho that I ordered. The restaurant itself is very chic and modern. The host was friendly and accomodating. Service-wise this place is great and all of the food smelled and looked delicious. As a disclaimer, I LOVE pho and am used to the pho dishes in the Los Angeles area (California, USA). I guess the pho in London is generally different from the pho in LA. It was just very very different from what I am used to. The broth is much darker/thicker and the noodles were different as well. They were extra thick, reminiscint of fettuccini noodles rather than thinner like vermicelli. I did not think that it was particularly bad, it just did not fit well with my taste-buds, especially since I was expecting the same kind of pho as I am used to eating back home.

DFKv-NuDMja_7PUSpqcqwg.text: Service is good, food is amazing! A bit too small though for weekends. Old street is quite busy so you end up waiting in a long queue.

VXBG35xUAOUBS4lVs_uJlw.text: A very busy restaurant split over two levels. The first time I came here for takeaway, I was left very disappointed as the quality of food didn't match my expectations (many people had said to me that it's one of the best Vietnamese restaurants in London) but then I did get takeaway on a Sunday afternoon, so my order was probably the only thing going through the kitchen at that time. Anyway, I put my dislike aside and recently went in. We were lucky to get a table as the place was rammed. The menu is large but not too big that they give you 30 variations on the same dish, as some of it's Kingsland Road neighbours seem to do. Service is very very friendly and helpful. The crowd that evening was a mix of people in the know, office workers and a few couples trying to have a romantic evening (which is hard if you're looking for any privacy as the tables are set so close together!) Many of the dishes have a theatre to them, with burners heating the food or additional preparation being done at your table. The prices are reasonable and the wine list fairly large, which I didn't expect. Second time round, the food quality was outstanding. I think my advice would be to go when it's busy (most of the time) and not when it's quiet (erm.. a Sunday afternoon!)

E4UB9dJuY9Dwl3lnbluPMw.text: Not that great I'm afraid. We shared the mixed seafood starter which consisted of battered squid which was ok a softshell crab that left a weird aftertaste and battered prawns with the shell still on, probably very authentic but a pain to peel. Mains of shaking beef luc lac was good, flavourful and tender whereas duck with mangetout and pak choi was a bit bland. Service was ok but not very attentive and rice with mains arrived only after reminding them twice. There are lots of other better place on Kingsland road a five minutes walk away.

t1TP_PoIDe67stbliHJxGg.text: shoreditch is famous for its vietnamese restaurants. I have tried a number of them but this is indeed my favoutite one. Good service although I dont think they take bookings. The food is just amazing!!

BVEIgb8ajcfrn9ZeNV92KA.text: Awesome place for something a little more than your usual Kingsland Road Vietnamese but without an obvious increase in price. In a cramped restaurant with trippy wallpaper you can sample some real unusual delights, all matched with top wine choices. Expect to queue at busy times but be prepared for a treat when you do get seated

Jmpp-3l4PygX2j-hTyQwoA.text: Great, Good, Yummy if you can get in. So popular and too tiny to keep you all happy. Authentic Vietnamese cuisine - fresh and meaty. Soft shell crab is highly recommended. Best to go here early week when they can accommodate you.

neEQJaNm1sMYXCSy2wH2dw.text: Great food, great service and a very good quality/price ratio! I recomend the lamb comin and the red sea prawn curry! If you're really into spicy the chicken curry proves it's effectiveness against colds and flu :)

7kTDYc3oX6zADm6b1pY0bQ.text: Legendary vietnamese restaurant in East London and every bit as good as I was told. It is a bit too small for the rush for it, so reservations or early arrival are highly recommended to avoid disappointment. The menu isn't too big, which I find both easier to navigate as well as ... trustworthy. We were not disappointed: The food was fresh (yes, fresh!), good portions and there is no long wait. The staff was somewhat "professional" rather than "personal" with us, but as mentioned before it is an extremely busy and popular place. Verdict: Probably the best meal for a tenner I ever had in London. All of East London seems to be in on it, so have a back-up plan on the weekend. I cannot imagine how you would fit larger groups on peak times.

BknqCLU75zRcfta6jlUMEQ.text: Pro-tip: the spring rolls come from the less fashionable restaurant across the street.

kbegPr3nguvEA5GOh84HtQ.text: Very good Vietnamese food at a decent price. The staff are friendly and efficient. The restaurant is small and can be a bit noisy when its busy. It's definitely worth booking in advance on weekends to make sure you get a table.

kEBgliGJy198DbaBjTrIAw.text: Unashamedly bad serviceFirst, our group walks in, a group of 3 on a Sunday afternoon mind you. We receive the menu and almost immediately are asked if we are ready to order. We reply that we aren't, the other two in my group look very confused about the menu. They asked clarifying questions about nearly every item on the menu rather than the waitress volunteering to help walk them through it. At a certain point I decided to step in and just walk them through it myself. The waitress offerred to bring us prawn crackers (which never came). Finally, we ordered our food. When it came, one girl's food came almost 15 minutes before our food. She was almost finished eating by the time we got our Pho. Now, I haven't had much Pho experience in London, but I have in other cities, and this was far from great.Finally, after we finished our meal, we were owed a 3rd course (dessert) from the set menu. Again, after 15min or so of the waitress floating around nervously, she finally asked if we wanted the bill, to which I responded by asking if we were getting our dessert. She looked confused, went back to the till, and put in our dessert order, for which we had to wait another 10 minutes or so. Then came the most painful part... paying the bill.It was a simply manner of splitting 3 ways. A very simply request (asking to break a 20-pound note into 10s) became very complicated quickly. The waitress said she couldn't open the till without a purchase. I handed her the 20 and said, ok, then just give me two 10s when a purchase is made. Then she said she didn't have 10s. Fine. So I asked if we could split the bill 3 ways, and she said we couldn't. Finally I just gave up. I asked her what we could do to check out. She came with a card reader and asked who was going to pay. What??After 30 minutes of back-and-forth arguing, we (finally!) realized that, in fact, we COULD split the bill 3 ways. All this, and a 15% service charge tacked on to the bill for laughably crappy service and sub-par food.

lE895JgkHG-w248kllazag.text: Really lovely Vietnamese restaurant. amazing food and wine glasses like massive fish bowls!Its on buzzing Old Street and well placed for a good night out. Staff are friendly too!

GKI4MhXcAEK7WoLYbOidAw.text: The staff are ok but the food is well above average vietnamese fare. Fresh and tasty. If you love meat this place has some great dishes. Seafood, the same. The Salt + Chilli Tofu is gorgeous - great for veggie and vegan too. Last time I went I sat next to a guy that has been coming every week for a fair few years - he had some great recommendations - the beef ceviche especially. This is my favourite vietnamese in an area that is saturated with them.

1yHzLvMp7JrbFsSawAQpfA.text: One of the best restaurants in London! It is not really located in a tourist place but worth a visit! I love the pho( rice noodle with clear soup) and recommend special fried rice! It tastes simple and fantastic!!I also recommend Bánh xèo. Menu says it is Vietnamese style pizza but I rather categorize it is Vietnamese style omlette. You can see people queuing often so better to book the table if you go busy time.Service is very quick but stuff is not that friendly.

PVA1pBgdwuS3Vcp0hO5_Aw.text: Okay. I finally got around to eating here. And now I'm feeling like a big dummy for all the years I didn't. I mean, the place is even walking distance from my flat.
