Sheesh! What was I thinking? Oh well. So yeah, it's good food. Lots of flavour. Much tastier than I expected - and I had high hopes based on a few raves from friends. Service is kinda spacey  but so what? It's cheap-n-delicious Vietnamese food! Go for the pho with homemade crab balls! Best Vietnamese in London? Maybe.

ar9QOT9LCqetRcVDRPPuXA.text: I went here after seeing a queue here everytime I walked by there.  I went in there once to find out what the fuss was all about.  I tried their la vong grilled fish.  The saffron and noodles reminded me of how my grandma used to cook them.  It is a really good appetizer especially if they cook it for you at the table.  Sometimes service is too busy and they don't do that for you.  Pho here was just alright.  Not bad but not mind blasting good.  Lots of variety in their menu.

7xWeV7fiwCe61pbwQB13Pw.text: Cay Tre is a restaurant whose unbelievably bland appearance belies the extraordinary quality of its food. Indeed, it's almost as if the standard of Cay Tre's appearance is inversely proportional to the standard of its grub. Which is, in my opinion, the best Vietnamese in the whole of Shoreditch.Sandwiched in between Old Street's minicab offices and cornershops, Cay Tre serves beautifully fresh and expertly prepared Vietnamese food both in its tiny restaurant and to take away. If you do want to eat in ensure you make a booking well in advance, I've tried to get a table at a moments notice and have literally waited hours to eat.

iOnZbsznISNkRnrV-mdE-g.text: Small, unassuming, you wouldn't really take notice of it when walking past, or at least I didn't anyway. Until one day someone took me here for a spot of what I thought was going to be a quick light lunch, but turned out to be a very enjoyable and indulging meal. We went a little crazy with our order and as per usual with me, over ordered. To start we had one of their salads and then Vietnamese spring rolls, which were served cold with the expected fillings of vermicelli and chicken and flavoured with chilli, mint, lime and fish sauce. Then we had their famous shaking beef fillet mignon, called bo luc lac, cooked deliciously with a spot of cognac and served with chilli sauce, a side of stir fried greens. The soft shelled crab we ordered was the weakest out of the dishes as instead of having a crisp bite to it, it came out a little soggy, but despite this it was still tasty.Cay Tre's menu is impressive and serves a wide, authentic range of true Vietnamese food. We came on a Saturday lunchtime near closing time, so there weren't that many people, which meant we had quick service. I hear that it can get really packed during the evenings on the weekend, so be sure to pre- book.

HDDdK8YIeeiknLQtlqxhug.text: I'm a big fan of Cay Tre. I seem to remember that an Evening Standard food writer voted it in her top 5 restaurants in London. What makes this decision more interesting is that it is clearly based on food quality, not flash or expense. This is probably the most basic setting in which I have had a delicious meal. I have had so many good dishes here, they are all packed with fresh herbs and spices. It's a welcome change to the ever-present Thai explosion around London. Not that I don't love Thai, but Vietnamese food is really worth an exploration. The dishes generally are drier and less creamy than Thai, which also makes them less calorific. Sorry to sound like a typical girl, but these things are sometimes important! One of my favourite starters is the Vietnamese pancakes. Look out for the noodle and fish starter for two which is brought to the table by your waitress and prepared in front of you. If you like fresh fish, I would go for the oven baked mackerel for a main which comes wrapped in a banana leaf. You get the whole fish and it is monumentally cheap, about £6.95. It's definitely true that you can eat like a king here, for a very small price. Well worth a visit.

h-ye6d8JUxuXj_Av14Y0zg.text: Really refreshing experience. I went for lunch with a friend and would definitely try it again in the evening. She had a Vietnamese salad which was supposed to be a starter but was enormous and bursting with flavour. I had a gorgeous vermicelli one dish meal with crab meat and prawns which really filling, crunchy with fresh beansprouts and not remotely greasy (which some stir fried noodles can be). Highly worth a visit if you're near Old Street

J-VR7KvGQDd8ghrT_c_wVQ.text: Fantastic food, great flavours. The crispy long fish is really good, as is the piggy aubergine dish. Great vietnamese coffee as well.

W6XXZE2raqt4jBhtLptz1g.text: I'm very surprised that nobody's commented on this place apart from the owner. It's a local legend. Food is fantastic. It's very busy at lunchtime, with local workers, and in the evening too. Highly recommended.

5J1Fc14iWKwuMxsqF2_7uA.text: was visiting from NYC and came here upon some friends' recommendations.  the wait for a non-sharing table was about 30 mins for a rainy friday night, the staff nicely offered us seats in the back while waiting so we didnt have to stand with everyone else. really chic decor, fast service, decent food and very reasonable prices in London standards (New Yorkers will find it way overpriced!!). not sure what the hype is all about though, as the food was just OK. there's nothing special about it. have had way better vietnamese food. but i guess it's a good hang out spot if you're in the neighborhood.

JyVqXXtELzR36gw_LQSsIA.text: Yum. Yum. Yum. The menu here was so extensive that I wasn't sure what to order. I ended up getting some grilled tofu and sauteed greens. I'd likely go for meat over tofu next time as the tofu was a bit bland. But the greens totally made up for it. They were garlicky and delicious!
